awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Machine learning-powered simulation of additive manufacturing for real-time design and process optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to accelerate larger-scale adoption of additive manufacturing (AM) through ultrafast engineering simulation software. The AM industry was worth $12.6 billion in 2020 and holds great potential in providing advanced designs and enabling distributed supply chains for the US aerospace, medical, and automotive industries. However, AM is facing slow adoption due to trial and error processes casued by the lack of an efficient and reliable engineering workflow. The proposed ultrafast simulation technology may provide real-time predictions of possible manufacturing issues for AM parts in the design phase, thereby reducing manufacturing failures and prototyping. The project also seeks to generate systematic knowledge of how machine learning can help overcome some long-lasting fundamental challenges in scientific computing and help advance engineering software used for digital manufacturing. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project integrates machine learning with finite element methods (FEM) to develop a proof-of-concept for 3-5 orders of magnitude faster process simulation software for AM used to predict manufacturing failures due to high temperature, residual distortion, and residual stresses. The traditional computation method for part-scale AM simulation takes hours to days and relies on an iterative, layer-wise approach. The proposed project seeks to replace the most time-consuming steps in the traditional simulation method with deep learning and implement a one-step approach. The proposed hybrid data-driven plus physical simulation framework includes the development a feature-driven, deep learning model and a process parameter-based transfer learning model, and coupling these models with the finite element method. The project also aims to apply and benchmark hybrid datasets from AM physical modelling, three-dimentional (3D) scanning of manufactured parts, and in-situ monitoring for training and model scalability. The team seeks to demonstrate technological advantages through pilot testing with streamlined user interfaces and application programming interfaces (APIs) developed in this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project has addressed the critical need for streamlined and scalable engineering solutions in the additive manufacturing sector, specifically targeting the reduction of operational costs in trial and error for service providers and original equipment manufacturers. Traditional simulation methods have proven insufficient, suffering from limitations in accuracy, computational speed, and usability. The project has successfully developed and validated an ultrafast process simulation technology that significantly enhances manufacturing efficiency and reliability.

The project has achieved advancement in developing an ultrafast and highly precise simulation technology for thermal prediction in metal powder bed fusion process. The technology represents a substantial leap forward, providing predictions with resolutions of 10-30 microns and a timestep granularity of 1-10 milliseconds, capable of scaling to full part dimensions. The technology framework offers a speed up of 3-5 order of magnitudes compared to traditional computational method such as finite element method and computational fluid dynamics simulation, delivering accurate melt-pool and full part temperature predictions in real time without requiring supercomputer resources. The technology’s capabilities have been validated with potential customers, showing minimal errors and providing enhanced analytical capabilities that allow for the detection of thermal inhomogeneities and optimization of printing parameters.  

The project provides significant benefits to the field of additive manufacturing and beyond. The ultrafast thermal simulation model developed in this project:

  1. Enables manufacturers to drastically reduce simulation time from hours to milliseconds, thus speeding up the design to production lifecycle.
  2. Offers scalable solutions from melt-pool scale to full part-scale, accommodating a wider range of manufacturing scenarios and increasing the technology's applicability.
  3. Enhances the quality and reliability of 3D printed metal parts, potentially leading to broader adoption in industries such as aerospace, automotive, and healthcare.
  4. Facilitates a more in-depth understanding and optimization of manufacturing processes, leading to less material waste and increased operational efficiency.

The project has proved a hybrid physical and deep learning simulation framework can achieve real-time prediction with great accuracy. The project also developed and demonstrated a data generation workflow specifically tailored for additive manufacturing can greatly reduce the time needed for training and optimizing the simulation models. The project has engaged with leading industry partners to further validate the commercial opportunities in integrate the simulation technology into their machine and their operations. The continuation of this work will set the stage for further innovations in the field, leading to greater efficiencies and broader adoption of additive manufacturing technologies.

 


Last Modified: 04/26/2024
Modified by: Runze Huang
